intro: Tithymalus cyrtophyllus, commonly known as the golden bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to southern Europe and parts of western Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, golden-yellow flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves. Its flowers are tubular at the base and flare out into a bell shape, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Tithymalus cyrtophyllus thrives in well-drained soils and full sun to partial shade, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and borders.
